normalised: Load shedding, or "power cuts" as we desi folks often call them, is essentially when the power company intentionally cuts off electricity supply to certain areas. Why? Well, usually it is because the demand for electricity is higher than what the power grid can handle. Think peak summer months when everyone's A C is blasting at full speed, or during Diwali when the whole nation is lit up brighter than a Bollywood premiere remember that scene in "Om Shanti Om"? So much light!

normalised: Now, there are a bunch of reasons why we face these situations. Sometimes it is because of old, creaky infrastructure that is overdue for an upgrade. Imagine an electricity grid like your grandfather's old scooter – it works, but not always reliably! Other times, it could be due to a shortage of coal or other fuels needed to power the power plants. And, of course, there is always the ever present possibility of technical issues – a blown transformer here, a damaged cable there.

normalised: Load shedding is a pain, no doubt. But understanding why it happens and taking small steps to conserve energy can help make things a little bit brighter for everyone.
